block.p: AUTO RACING Pole for Mario Andretti

Mario Andretti outperformed his son Michael in a record-setting duel yesterday at Michigan International Speedway, taking the pole position for tomorrow's Marlboro 500 with a lap of 230.150 miles an hour. Michael was timed in 230.056 on the track, located in Brooklyn, Mich. The elder Andretti's fast lap gave him the 65th pole of his career -- extending his own series record -- but his first since Miami in 1987. It also made the 52-year-old Andretti the oldest man ever to win an Indy-car pole. The only official laps faster than the one by Andretti yesterday came in May during the Indianapolis 500 qualifying, when Roberto Guerrero had four laps faster than 232 miles an hour. (AP) GOLF Morgan Chips to Lead

Gil Morgan, after a three-hour rain delay, used a 20-foot chip-in to resurrect his game and took the lead yesterday midway through the rain-shortened second round of the Canon Greater Hartford Open in Cromwell, Conn. Morgan was struggling but birdied two of his final four holes to move to six-under-par 64, 2-under for the day. Kenny Knox, the first-round leader, and Billy Ray Brown, the defending champion, were tied with Morgan at 6-under and will resume second-round play this morning. Knox had finished four holes and Brown six when play was suspended for good with 80 players still on the course. (AP)

Three Tied for L.P.G.A. Lead: Robin Walton shot a five-under 67 and Sherri Steinhauer a 68 to join Florence Descampe of Belgium atop the leader board after two rounds of the L.P.G.A. Bay State Classic in Canton, Mass. Walton, Steinhauer and Descampe, who had a 70 yesterday, were at 6-under-par 138 after 36 holes at the Blue Hill Country Club. Dottie Mochrie shot a 67 to get within a stroke of the lead. (AP) TENNIS Borg Trails; Rain Falls

Persistent rain played havoc with the quarterfinals Friday at the U.S. Pro Championships at the Longwood Cricket Club in Brookline, Mass. Several matches were suspended until today. Aleksandr Volkov led Bjorn Borg, 6-4, 2-6, 3-0, as the Russian capitalized on several weak forehand returns by the Swede. The winner of the Borg-Volkov match will face either Richey Reneberg or Jeff Tarango. Reneberg was leading Tarango, 6-3, 3-2, when rain stopped their match. In another match, MaliVai Washington led a qualifier, Eric Amend, by 2-1, in the first set. Washington is the No. 17 player in the world, while Amend is No. 607. Top-seeded Lendl will face unseeded Greg Rusedski in his quarterfinal match today. (AP) LACROSSE England Tops Iroquois

The under-19 world championship tournament in lacrosse began yesterday at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., with England defeating the Iroquois Nation, 14-8, in the opening game. The Iroquois team, made up of American Indians from upstate New York, is accorded national status by the International Lacrosse Federation. Canada played Japan, and the United States team met Australia in other games last night at Hofstra Stadium. The six teams will continue the round-robin competition until next Saturday night, when the top two will play for the championship. BASEBALL Game Interrupted

The Reviving Baseball in the Inner Cities all-star game between the Harlem RBI and Los Angeles RBI teams at Yankee Stadium was stopped with the score tied at 2-2 in the first inning yesterday because of rain. The game, matching players from youth programs for teen-agers, will resume at 9 A.M. today at RBI Field on First Avenue and 100th Street in East Harlem.
